questions.text: A 66-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with complaints of progressive back pain and loss of height over the past year. She has a history of early menopause at 45 years and no history of hormone replacement therapy. A DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) scan of her lumbar spine reveals a T-score of -3.5. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis based on her T-score?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

A T-score of -2.5 or below on DEXA confirms a diagnosis of osteoporosis.

  • Bone densitometry using DEXA is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis.
  • The T-score compares the patient's bone mineral density (BMD) to a young adult reference population.
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines:
    • Normal: T-score ≥ -1 (Option A ruled out)
    • Osteopenia: T-score between -1 and -2.5 (Option B ruled out)
    • Osteoporosis: T-score ≤ -2.5

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with dull aching pain in the left thigh and an increase in the size of his femur. There is no history of trauma. X-ray of the femur shows a well-demarcated advancing wedge-shaped area of radiolucency , as given. Paget's disease was diagnosed. Which phase of Paget's disease is most likely responsible for this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given x-ray shows a 'blade of grass' or 'flame-shaped' ;appearance. It is characteristic of the osteolytic phase of Paget' disease.

  • Paget's disease is a disorder of abnormal bone turnover.
  • It is a chronic disease of bone remodeling characterized by abnormal osteoclastic activity(and later by increased osteoblastic activity) resulting in replacement of normal bone with excessive, weak and hyper-vascular bone.
  • Paget's disease progresses in three classic phases:
    • Osteolytic phase
      • It is Characterized by increased osteoclastic activity causing focal radiolucency.
      • This phase shows the "blade of grass" or "flame-shaped" appearance on X-ray, especially in long bones like the femur or tibia.
    • Mixed phase (Option B ruled out)
      • There is both osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity. X-rays show a combination of lytic and sclerotic areas.
    • Sclerotic phase (Option C ruled out)
      • Predominantly osteoblastic activity leads to dense, sclerotic, thickened bone with a "cotton wool" appearance in the skull.
  • X-ray findings depend on the phase of Paget's disease and summarised as:
    • Lytic phase
      • Flame shaped/Blade of grass appearance
      • Osteoporosis circumscripta
    • Mixed phase
      • Picture frame vertebra
      • Ivory vertebra
      • Cotton wool skull
    • Blastic phase
      • Tam O shanter skull

questions.text: When treating osteoporosis with alendronate, what is the most common side effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastrointestinal irritation, especially gastritis and peptic ulceration, is the most common adverse effect of oral alendronate.

  • Alendronate is a bisphosphonate used in the management of osteoporosis.
  • It works by inhibiting osteoclastic bone resorption.
  • Alendronate is generally given orally in a dose of 70 mg/week.
  • Patients are advised to take tablet with a full glass of water and not to lie down for at least half an hour as these can cause gastritis , esophagitis , gastric or duodenal ulcers

Explanation of other options:

Osteonecrosis of jaw bone (Option A) : Though a known serious complication of bisphosphonates, especially after dental procedures, it is rare and not the most common side effect.

Dry mucus membrane (Option C) : Not commonly associated with bisphosphonates; dry mouth is more typical with anticholinergic drugs.

Insomnia (Option D) : Not a recognized or common side effect of alendronate. Sleep disturbances are not typically reported.

choices.text: Increased osteoclast activity due to inflammation

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with generalized bone pain and history of multiple low-impact fractures over the past 2 years. She has a stooped posture and decreased height. Lab investigations show normal calcium and phosphate levels but low serum albumin and total protein. DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -3.2. Which of the following best explains how protein loss contributes to osteoporosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Protein deficiency leads to reduced collagen production, which impairs the organic bone matrix, thereby contributing to osteoporosis.

  • Osteoporosis is characterized by reduced bone mass and disrupted microarchitecture.
  • Bone consists of:
    • Inorganic mineral component (mainly calcium hydroxyapatite)
    • Organic matrix (predominantly type I collagen and non-collagenous proteins)
  • Protein deficiency reduces collagen synthesis, weakening the bone's structural integrity even if mineral levels are normal.
  • Therefore, in malnutrition, chronic illness, or low albumin states, osteoporosis may occur due to compromised bone matrix quality, not just calcium loss.

Explanation of other options:

Increased parathyroid hormone activity (Option A) : Seen in hyperparathyroidism, not directly linked to protein loss.

Reduced intestinal calcium absorption (Option B) : Related to vitamin D deficiency, not directly due to protein deficiency.

Increased osteoclast activity due to inflammation (Option D) : Seen in chronic inflammatory states (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis), but not the primary mechanism in protein-loss-related osteoporosis.

questions.text: The drug, Denosumab is used in the treatment of osteoporosis, as well as in the treatment of giant cell tumor of bone. Which of the following is the mechanism by which Denosumab acts?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Denosumab is an antibody to RANKL, essential for promoting osteoclastogenesis.

  • Bone resorption in the human body is mediated via RANK ligand, which when produced by osteoblasts(under PTH influence)/tumor cells, attaches to the RANK receptor on the osteoclast and causes its activation.
  • Denosumab(AMG 162) is a recombinant human immunoglobulin G2(IgG2) antibody functionally similar to OPG with affinity and specificity for RANKL.
  • Denosumab inhibits the RANKL/RANK formation on the osteoblast and hence prevents the osteoblast-osteoclast interaction by decreasing bone resorption.
  • The effect is an increase in bone mass and strength in both cortical and trabecular bone primarily by antiresorptive action.

Explanation of other options:

Inhibit osteoclast maturation (Option A) : Denosumab does not directly inhibit osteoclast maturation; rather, it binds to RANKL, preventing its interaction with RANK on osteoclast precursors, thereby inhibiting osteoclast activation, not specifically their maturation process.

Stimulate bone formation (Option B) : Denosumab is anti-resorptive, not anabolic. Drugs like teriparatide stimulate bone formation by acting on osteoblasts.

Accelerate bone mineralization (Option D) : Bone mineralization is not directly affected by Denosumab. Agents like vitamin D help in mineralization, while Denosumab primarily inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption.

questions.text: 70 years old male, known case of chronic renal failure suffers from a pathological fracture of his right femur. What could be the underlying mechanism that has caused this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In chronic kidney disease, secondary hyperparathyroidism arises due to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, leading to increased bone resorption and fragility.

  • Chronic renal failure leads to:
    • Reduced phosphate excretion which leads to hyperphosphatemia
    • Decreased renal conversion of vitamin D to its active form (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol) leads to hypocalcemia
  • Both hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia stimulate the parathyroid glands to secrete more parathyroid hormone (PTH).
  • This compensatory rise in PTH is termed secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • PTH increases osteoclast activity, causing bone resorption, weakening bones, and making them susceptible to pathological fractures, particularly in weight-bearing bones such as the femur - a classic feature of renal osteodystrophy.

Explanation of other options:

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option A) : It involves autonomous PTH secretion, typically from a parathyroid adenoma. It is not secondary to chronic renal failure.

Scurvy (Option C) : Caused by vitamin C deficiency, it impairs collagen synthesis, leading to gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and fragile capillaries - not typically associated with renal failure or pathological femoral fractures.

Hyperphosphatemia (Option D) : Although present in chronic kidney disease, it is a contributing factor, not the primary mechanism. The body's response (secondary hyperparathyroidism) is what causes the bone disease and fracture

questions.text: A 3 year old child presented with progressive anemia, hepatosplenomegaly and osteomyelitis of the jaw with pathological fracture. His x-rays show diffuse sclerosis of bones. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteopetrosis is a congenital disorder marked by defective osteoclast function, causing diffuse bony sclerosis, anemia due to marrow space narrowing, and pathological fractures.

Osteopetrosis is also known as Marble bone disease ( or Albers-Schonberg disease) :

  • Defect is in bone resorption due to abnormal function of osteoclasts.
  • Defective bone resorption results in uniformly thickened dense bones, often without distinction between cortical and cancellous regions.
  • The bones are dense but brittle therefore known as marble bone disease.
  • Inheritance is both AD & AR. The AR form dies early in life. The AD form is of milder variety.
  • Due to abnormal thickening of bone, there will be narrowing of cranial nerve foramina resulting in cranial nerve palsies causing blindness and deafness.
  • The medullary canal usually gets obliterated by bone deposition leading to bone marrow failure.
  • This causes pancytopenia. Neutropenia manifests as recurrent infections especially mandibular osteomyelitis. Thrombocytopenia presents as easy bruising and bleeding. The anemia will be classically progressive as more and more of the medullary canal gets filled up with bone.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoporosis (Option B) : Characterized by decreased bone mass and increased porosity, not sclerosis; typically seen in older individuals, not young children.

Paget's disease (Option C) : Affects older adults, with a mixed lytic-sclerotic pattern, not diffuse sclerosis in a child.

Alkaptonuria (Options D) : A metabolic disorder causing ochronosis and degenerative joint disease, not associated with anemia or diffuse sclerosis in early childhood.

questions.text: A 30 year old female presents to the OPD with generalized body pain and fatigue. Blood investigations show normal calcium, decreased phosphate, elevated PTH and elevated ALP. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin D deficiency will have:

  • Low calcium(early stage) or normal calcium(once the calcium homeostasis mechanism sets in)
  • Low phosphate
  • High alkaline phosphatase
  • High parathormone level(secondary hyperparathyroidism)

Explanation of other options:

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option B) :

  • High calcium
  • Low phosphate
  • High alkaline phosphatase
  • High parathormone level

Osteoporosis (Option C) all these parameters will be normal.

Paget's disease (Option D) calcium and phosphate levels are normal. Serum alkaline phosphatase is raised.

choices.text: Decreased Ca, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase
Increased Ca, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase
Decreased Ca and phosphate but increased alkaline phosphatase
Normal Ca, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with complaints of chronic lower back pain and a recent low-impact fracture of the distal radius. She has a sedentary lifestyle and no history of steroid use. DEXA scan shows a T-score of -2.9. Her blood workup is ordered to investigate the cause of her bone fragility. Which of the following best describes the expected biochemical profile in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In osteoporosis, biochemical markers such as serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase are typically normal, distinguishing it from metabolic bone diseases.

Osteoporosis is a condition where the total bone mass or bone density is reduced. It is a quantitative deficiency of bone; however, the quality of bone is very good. Hence, there is no biochemical abnormality in osteoporosis.

choices.text: I/V Parathormone is useful in severe osteoporosis
Bisphosphonates are the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

I/V Parathormone is not used in osteoporosis; intermittent subcutaneous PTH (teriparatide) is used. Hence the statement is incorrect.

  • PTH analogues such as teriparatide and Preotact can be used for treatment of osteoporosis, however they are given as subcutaneous injections.
  • Recombinant Parathormone/Teriparatide Parathyroid hormone directly acts on osteoblasts and promotes new bone formation.
  • Although a continuous infusion of PTH stimulates bone resorption, small pulses in the form of once daily subcutaneous injections(20 microgram/day) have been shown to improve bone formation and reduce the risk of both vertebral and nonvertebral fractures.
  • Long-term therapy for 1.5 to 2 years is advised for both men and postmenopausal women. Cost is high and its anabolic effects are masked in patients on bisphosphonates, so best is to give it as monotherapy.
  • However, it is the drug of choice in patients with bisphosphonate resistant osteoporosis.
  • Side effects include gastric intolerance, dermatitis and arthralgias.

Explanation of other options:

T score is less than -2.5 (Option B) : A T-score ≤ -2.5 on DEXA confirms the diagnosis of osteoporosis.

Bisphosphonates are the mainstay of treatment ( Option C) :Bisphosphonates like alendronate inhibit bone resorption and are first-line therapy.

Z score less than -2.5 (Option D) : In premenopausal women and younger individuals; a Z-score < -2.0 is considered below the expected range for age, though T-score is used for postmenopausal women and older men.

questions.text: As per current recommendations which vitamin is required with Vitamin D for treatment of osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin K is essential for the activation of vitamin K-dependent proteins, which are involved not only in blood coagulation but in bone metabolism and the inhibition of arterial calcification.

  • Recently many studies have proved the role of vitamin K in osteoporosis(gamma-carboxylation of osteocalcin) and vitamin D is increasingly being given to prevent and treat osteoporosis.
  • Vitamin K deficiency decreases bone mineral density and increases the risk of fractures.
  • Vitamin K is primarily a cofactor in the enzymatic reaction that converts glutamate residues into gamma-carboxyglutamate residues in vitamin K-dependent proteins.
  • The results of recent studies have suggested that concurrent use of menaquinone and vitamin D may substantially reduce bone loss.

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin A (Option A) : Excess Vitamin A is actually associated with increased risk of osteoporosis and fractures; it is not recommended as part of osteoporosis treatment.

Vitamin B (Option B) : While B-complex vitamins (like B6, B12, and folate) are important for overall health, they do not play a direct or essential role in bone mineralization or osteoporosis management.

Vitamin C (Option C) : Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, but it is not a standard co-therapy with Vitamin D in osteoporosis treatment.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16030366/

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Osteogenesis imperfecta?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Blue sclera is one of the clinical features of osteogenesis imperfecta.

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease, is due to defective collagen type 1 synthesis.
  • It is inherited mostly as an autosomal dominant trait but autosomal recessive pattern is also seen in severe forms of the disease.
  • Clinical features include
    • Skeletal system
      • Fractures occur with the slightest trauma
      • Multiple B/L symmetrical fractures are seen
      • MC bone #: femur > tibia
      • Fracture healing is normal
      • #s usually malunites causing deformities
      • Wormian bones - intra sutural bones in the skull
      • Ring shaped epiphysis will be seen
    • Ocular signs
      • Blue sclera
      • Saturn ring
      • Arcus Juvenilis
    • Auditory - Deafness
    • Teeth
      • Dentigerous imperfecta
      • Normal enamel but abnormal dentin
      • Discolored, Brittle teeth are seen
      • Lower incisors are most affected

Explanation of other options:

Anterior uveitis (Option B) : This is typically seen in inflammatory conditions like ankylosing spondylitis, not in osteogenesis imperfecta.

Cataract (Option C) : Cataracts are age-related or due to metabolic disorders but are not a typical feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Defective fracture healing (Option D) : In osteogenesis imperfecta, fracture healing is usually normal, though fractures occur frequently due to brittle bones.

questions.text: A patient is brought with complaints of progressive fatigue, abdominal distension, and intermittent bone pain. On examination, he has pallor and massive hepatosplenomegaly. X-ray of both knees reveals metaphyseal flaring of the distal femur as shown in the given x-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The metaphyseal flaring seen is called the 'Erlenmeyer flask deformity' which is a characteristic of Gaucher's disease.

  • Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.
  • This leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages (called Gaucher cells), primarily within the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • Accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the bone marrow interferes with normal bone modeling, leading to:
    • Metaphyseal flaring → Erlenmeyer flask deformity
      • Due to infiltration of marrow with Gaucher cells, the normal bone remodeling at metaphyses is disrupted, resulting in flared, widened metaphyseal ends, giving the characteristic flask-like shape on X-ray.
    • Bone pain, pathological fractures
    • Hepatosplenomegaly and anemia due to marrow infiltration
  • Bone involvement is common and often precedes systemic manifestations.
  • Characteristic radiological finding:
    • Erlenmeyer flask deformity -flaring of the metaphyseal region of long bones (especially distal femur), due to failure of normal metaphyseal remodeling.
  • Other skeletal features:
    • Bone pain due to marrow infiltration
    • Pathological fractures
    • Osteonecrosis (especially femoral heads)
    • Vertebral collapse in severe cases
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Anemia and thrombocytopenia (due to marrow infiltration)
    • Delayed growth
    • Neurological involvement (in neuronopathic types) - occasionally
  • Diagnosis:
    • Enzyme assay for glucocerebrosidase activity
    • Bone marrow biopsy may show Gaucher cells (macrophages with a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance)
  • Treatment:
    • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) - mainstay in non-neuronopathic forms
    • Supportive management for bone crises and orthopedic complications

Explanation of other options:

Thalassemia major (Option A) : Causes marrow expansion with 'hair-on-end' skull appearance, not Erlenmeyer deformity.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Options C) : Characterized by multiple fractures, blue sclera, and wormian bones but not metaphyseal flaring.

Rickets (Option D) : Shows cupping and fraying at metaphyses but not Erlenmeyer flask appearance.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with recurrent fractures, pallor, and delayed growth. Clinical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and signs of anemia. An X-ray of the foot is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diffuse bone sclerosis with loss of medullary cavity on X-ray , called as bone within bone appearance, is a hallmark of osteopetrosis.

  • Osteopetrosis is a rare congenital disorder of osteoclast dysfunction, resulting in:
    • Failure of normal bone resorption, leading to dense but brittle bones
    • Anemia and hepatosplenomegaly due to marrow space obliteration and extramedullary hematopoiesis
    • Radiographic features include generalized sclerosis, 'bone within bone' appearance, and absence of normal marrow cavity.
  • X-ray features of osteopetrosis:
    • Generalized osteosclerosis of bones.
    • Loss of cortico medullary differentiation
    • Grossly narrowed/absent medullary canal
    • Cube-like bones(carpals and tarsals)
    • Erlenmeyer flask deformity of distal femur
    • Sandwich vertebra
    • Endo Bone formation(bone within bone appearance)

Explanation of other options:

Osteoporosis (Option B) : Shows decreased bone density (osteopenia) and thinning of trabeculae, not sclerosis or 'bone within bone' appearance.

Osteomalacia (Option C) : Caused by defective mineralization; radiologically presents with Looser’s zones (pseudofractures) and decreased bone density, not increased sclerosis.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D) : Characterized by osteopenia, multiple fractures, and wormian bones, but not the 'bone within a bone' sign or diffuse sclerosis.

questions.text: A 60 year old man with chronic renal failure presents with back pain. His CT is shown below. What is the characteristic finding seen in the CT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rugger jersey spine is seen in Renal Osteodystrophy

  • Renal osteodystrophy is characterized by bone mineralization deficiency due to the electrolyte and endocrine abnormalities associated with chronic kidney disease.
    • The pathogenesis of renal osteodystrophy is multifactorial.
    • Hypocalcemia occurs due to the inability of the damaged kidney to convert vitamin D3 into its active form, calcitriol.
    • The hypocalcemia and lack of phosphate excretion by the damaged kidney causes hyperparathyroidism and secondary hyperphosphatemia.
  • DDs of Rugger jersey spine are given below.

Explanation of other options:

Bone within bone appearance (Option A) : This is seen in osteopetrosis, not in chronic renal failure. It shows dense bone layers within the metaphysis of long bones , not vertebral changes.

Picture frame vertebra (Option C) : Characteristic of Paget’s disease, where the vertebral margins become sclerotic and the center remains radiolucent ; distinct from the endplate sclerosis of rugger jersey spine.

Bamboo spine (Option D) : Seen in ankylosing spondylitis, where syndesmophytes bridge the vertebrae, giving a bamboo-like appearance-not associated with chronic kidney disease.

choices.text: Decreased PTH secretion, hypophosphatemia and hypocalcemia
Increased PTH secretion, hyperphosphatemia and hypocalcemia
Decreased PTH secretion, hypophosphatemia and hypercalcemia
Increased PTH secretion, hyperphosphatemia and hypercalcemia

questions.text: What laboratory findings would you expect to find in a patient newly diagnosed with renal osteodystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Decreased calcium, increased serum phosphate, increased alkaline phosphatase and increased parathyroid hormone are all characteristic of renal osteodystrophy

  • Renal osteodystrophy is characterized by bone mineralization deficiency due to the electrolyte and endocrine abnormalities associated with chronic kidney disease.
  • The pathogenesis of renal osteodystrophy is multifactorial.
  • Hypocalcemia occurs due to the inability of the damaged kidney to convert vitamin D3 into its active form, calcitriol and because there is loss of calcium through urine. There will also be phosphate retention as the failed kidneys cannot excrete phosphates.
  • The hypocalcemia and lack of phosphate excretion by the damaged kidney causes hyperparathyroidism and secondary hyperphosphatemia.

questions.text: Identify the given x-ray. Which of the following conditions is associated with it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given x-ray shows 'Looser zones' , which is a characteristic of Osteomalacia.

  • Looser zones are wide transverse lucencies traversing bone usually at right angles to the involved cortex and are associated most frequently with osteomalacia and rickets.
  • They are also called Milkman fractures or pseudo-fractures and considered a type of insufficiency fracture.
  • Typically, the fractures have sclerotic irregular margins and are often symmetrical.
  • Causes
    • Osteomalacia(most common)
    • Renal osteodystrophy
    • Fibrous dysplasia
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Paget's disease of bone

Osteomalacia is a metabolic bone disease characterized by inadequate mineralization of osteoid in adult bone, typically due to vitamin D deficiency, renal failure, or phosphate depletion.

  • A classic radiological finding in osteomalacia is the Looser's zone (also known as pseudofractures):
    • These appear as bilateral, symmetrical, transverse lucencies typically located in areas of mechanical stress like the medial femoral neck, pubic rami, ribs, and scapula.
    • They represent areas of incomplete fractures with unmineralized osteoid and often have sclerotic borders.
    • On X-ray, these lines are clear and transverse, unlike complete fractures, and they don't completely disrupt the bone cortex.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoporosis (Option A) : Involves loss of bone mass with thinning of trabeculae but does not produce Looser zones; fractures are more complete and without sclerotic margins.

Osteopetrosis (Option C) : Involves increased bone density due to osteoclast dysfunction; classic findings include bone within bone appearance-not Looser zones.

Osteosarcoma (Option D) : A malignant bone tumor showing sunburst pattern, Codman's triangle, or bone destruction with new bone formation-not pseudofractures.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with complaints of dull aching pain in his pelvis and increasing skull size. He also reports hearing loss in one ear and increased warmth over the left tibia. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase with normal calcium and phosphate levels. X-rays show thickened cortical bone with mixed lytic and sclerotic changes in the pelvis. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is Paget's disease, suggested by increased ALP, bone pain, hearing loss, and mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions and the treatment of choice is a bisphosphonate like alendronate.

  • Paget's disease is a chronic disorder of bone remodeling characterized by:
    • Excessive osteoclastic resorption followed by disorganized osteoblastic repair.
    • Leads to formation of structurally weak, enlarged, and deformed bones.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Skull involvement: enlarged head, hearing loss due to nerve compression
    • Tibia or femur involvement: bowing and warmth due to hypervascularity
    • Pelvic involvement: common and often picked up incidentally
    • Laboratory: Elevated ALP with normal calcium and phosphate
    • Radiology: Mixed lytic and sclerotic areas, cortical thickening, and “picture frame vertebrae” in spine
  • Treatment:
    • Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate) suppress osteoclast activity, reduce bone turnover, relieve symptoms, and improve bone strength.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recognized risk factor for osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Early menarche is associated with longer estrogen exposure, which is protective for bone health, making it not a risk factor for osteoporosis.

Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by reduced bone mass and microarchitectural deterioration, leading to increased fracture risk.

Risk Factors for Osteoporosis:

  • Old age
  • Thin built
  • Female SEX
  • Early menopause or late menarche
  • Prolonged amenorrhea>1 year
  • Oophorectomy during reproductive years
  • Treatment with osteoporosis causing drugs
  • Smoking (impairs osteoblast activity and reduces estrogen levels) (Option C ruled out)
  • Alcohol consumption (interferes with calcium absorption and bone remodeling)
  • High caffeine intake (interferes with calcium absorption and bone remodeling) (Option B ruled out)
  • Low calcium intake (limits mineralization of the bone matrix) (Option D ruled out)
  • Inactivity

questions.text: All of the following causes osteopenia except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteopetrosis is characterized by increased bone density (osteosclerosis) due to defective osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, and hence does not cause osteopenia.

  • Osteopenia is a condition where bone mineral density is lower than normal. It is considered to be a precursor to osteoporosis.
  • However, not every person diagnosed with osteopenia will develop osteoporosis. Technically, Osteopenia is defined as a bone mineral density T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • T-score:
    • T score is a value that we get when we compare the BMD of a patient with the BMD of a normal 30 year old person of the same gender and race.
  • World Health Organization classification based on T score are:
    • Normal is a T-score of -1.0 or higher
    • Osteopenia is defined as between -1.0 and -2.5
    • Osteoporosis is defined as -2.5 or lower.
  • Causes of Osteopenia-
    • Metabolic bone disease
    • Osteoporosis especially in Postmenopausal women
    • Rickets and Osteomalacia
    • Rheumatoid arthritis
    • Osteomyelitis
    • Osteonecrosis
    • Multiple myeloma
    • Celiac disease

Explanation of other options:

Rickets (Option A) : Rickets involves defective mineralization of the growing bone in children, leading to osteopenia and bone deformities.

Osteomalacia (Options B) : In adults, osteomalacia causes osteopenia due to accumulation of unmineralized osteoid.

Osteonecrosis (Options D) : Although it primarily causes localized bone death, the surrounding bone often shows osteopenia due to disuse or secondary changes.

choices.text: Proximal femur of the paretic side
Proximal Humerus of the paretic side

Explanation:

When a person is hemiplegic and bedridden for one year , changes in bone mineral density are first seen in proximal humerus

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue, diffuse bone pain, and difficulty walking. She has a history of celiac disease and has not been compliant with vitamin D supplementation. On examination, there is proximal muscle weakness and a waddling gait. Lab tests reveal low serum calcium, low phosphate, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. X ray was done and is given below. Which of the following X-ray findings is not consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Splaying of metaphysis is seen in rickets and not in osteomalacia.

  • Radiographic findings in Osteomalacia
    • The classical lesion of osteomalacia is the Looser zone, a thin transverse band of rarefaction in an otherwise normal-looking bone. These zones, seen especially in the shaft of long bones and the axillary edge of the scapula, are due to incomplete stress fractures which heal with callus lacking in calcium. (Option A ruled out)
    • Biconcave codfish vertebrae due to indentation on vertebral bodies by the intervertebral disk (Option B ruled out)
    • Trefoil or Champagne-glass pelvis (Option C ruled out)
    • Protrusio acetabuli.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of progressive joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the spine and large joints. She also notes that her urine darkens on standing. Examination reveals bluish-black pigmentation over the sclera and ear cartilage. Imaging shows degenerative changes in intervertebral discs and large joints. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The triad of dark urine on standing, early-onset arthritis, and pigment deposition is characteristic of alkaptonuria, a metabolic disorder involving homogentisic acid.

  • Alkaptonuria is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase, leading to accumulation of homogentisic acid (HGA).
  • Key orthopaedic and systemic features include:
    • Darkening of urine on exposure to air (oxidation of HGA)
    • Ochronosis: bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissues including cartilage, sclera, and ear
    • Early-onset degenerative arthritis, especially of the spine, knees, and hips
  • Radiographs may show:
    • Calcification of intervertebral discs
    • Narrowed disc spaces
    • Osteoarthritic changes at a relatively young age
  • Ochronosis refers to the pigment deposition, while alkaptonuria is the underlying metabolic cause.

Explanation of other options:

Phenylketonuria (Option B): A disorder of phenylalanine metabolism, presenting with intellectual disability and seizures, not joint pigment deposition or dark urine.

Tyrosinemia (Option C): Involves hepatorenal dysfunction due to accumulation of tyrosine metabolites; does not cause ochronosis or arthropathy.

Ochronosis (Option D): While ochronosis describes the clinical pigment deposition, it is a feature of alkaptonuria, not the primary diagnosis.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3978898/

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient from Bihar presented with generalized bone pain and had excess fluoride intake. He was diagnosed with fluorosis. Fluorosis of bone is commonly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fluorosis leads to osteosclerosis due to excessive fluoride stimulating osteoblastic activity and increasing bone density.

Cause of generalised osteosclerosis

  • Fluorosis
  • Paget's disease of bone
  • Renal osteodystrophy
  • Secondaries from prostate, other organs
  • Marble bone disease(osteopetrosis)
  • Engelmann's disease

Fluorosis

  • An osteosclerosis disease with excessive deposition in bone and soft tissue.
  • Due to excessive fluoride intake in drinking water(Normally it is less than 1 ppm)
  • Clinical feature:
    • Skeletal fluorosis: Back pain and joint pain, spine stiffness and paraesthesia of limbs.
    • Dental fluorosis: Earliest sign of fluorosis.
      • Mottling of enamel → best seen in incisors of upper jaw → teeth gets eroded and later falls off.
    • X-rays: Increased density and calcification in spine and pelvis.
    • Investigation: Increased fluoride in urine and drinking water.
    • Treatment: Decrease fluoride content in drinking water. Defluorination of the water is carried out as a public health programme. Patients improve symptomatically once the defluorinated water is used for some time.

Explanation of other options:

Osteopetrosis (Option A): A genetic disorder of defective osteoclast function causing diffuse bone sclerosis-not related to fluoride exposure.

Osteoporosis (Option B): Involves loss of bone mass and decreased bone density, the opposite of osteosclerosis.

Osteomalacia (Option D): Caused by defective bone mineralization, leading to soft bones, not increased bone density as seen in fluorosis.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3295994/

questions.text: A 65 year old female presented to the OPD with complaints of back pain for the last 2 years. X-ray of her lumbar spine is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shows codfish/biconcave vertebra which are classic findings of osteoporosis.

  • Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by:
    • Reduced bone mass and density
    • Normal mineralization
    • Common in postmenopausal women and the elderly
    • Predisposes to fragility fractures, especially of the spine, hip, and wrist
  • Spinal X-ray features:
    • Generalized radiolucency of vertebrae
    • Anterior wedge fractures
    • Biconcave (codfish) vertebrae due to compression
    • Loss of vertical trabeculae

Explanation of other options:

Paget's disease (Option A): Shows coarse trabeculae, mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions, and picture frame vertebrae-not generalized osteopenia.

Renal osteodystrophy (Option B): Associated with rugger jersey spine (sclerotic endplates), subperiosteal resorption-absent here.

Osteopetrosis (Option D): Characterized by generalized sclerosis, not radiolucency; spine shows sandwich vertebrae or bone within bone.
